Comparing the CO oxidation activity of free PdO and Pd2+ ions over PdO-CeO2/SiO2 catalysts Shu-Yuan Wang Na Li Ren-Mei Zhou Ling-Yun Jin Geng-Shen Hu Ji-Qing Lu Meng-Fei Luo * Key Laboratory of the Ministry of Education for Advanced Catalysis Materials, Institute of Physical Chemistry, Zhejiang Normal University, Jinhua 321004, China Key Laboratory of the Ministry of Education for Advanced Catalysis Materials, Institute of Physical Chemistry, Zhejiang Normal University Jinhua 321004 China * Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 579 82283910; fax: +86 579 82282595. Graphical abstract Aiming at comparing the CO oxidation activity of free PdO and Pd2+ ions, a series of PdO-CeO2/SiO2 catalysts were prepared via an impregnation method and the turnover frequencies of them were quantitatively evaluated. The catalysts were further characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET), temperature-programmed reduction (TPR), Raman technique and CO chemisorption. It was found that free PdO species and Pd2+ ions could be segregated efficiently by nitric acid treatment. The PdO-CeO2/SiO2 catalyst calcined at 600°C showed the highest activity. The results of CO chemisorption suggested that free PdO species had a higher activity than Pd2+ ions, and the turnover frequencies of them were 3.27×10−2 s−1 and 0.49×10−2 s−1, respectively. The activity of PdO-CeO2/SiO2 catalyst was higher than that of PdO/SiO2 catalyst. Moreover, the CO catalytic activity of PdO-CeO2/SiO2 catalyst could be assigned to the synergetic effect of free PdO and Pd2+ ions, and this effect could improve the CO catalytic activity of catalysts. Keywords PdO-CeO2/SiO2 catalyst CO oxidation Active site TOF 1 Introduction CO catalytic oxidation is very important in catalysis due to its many potential applications such as automobile exhaust purification [1,2], CO gas sensors [3,4], closed-eye carbon dioxide lasers [5], protective mask, etc. [6,7]. Many efforts have been paid to improve the catalytic activity of the catalysts for the CO oxidation [8,9]. It has been recognized that the ceria, used as both assistant and support [10,11], plays an important role for the CO oxidation. The ceria can improve the activity, selectivity, and the increased thermal stability of the noble metals (Pd, Pt) [12] catalysts and the non-noble metals (Cu) [13,14] catalysts remarkably. For example, the Pd-CeO2/Al2O3 catalyst was more active than the Pd/Al2O3 catalyst for CO oxidation [15]. In a more recent study by Oh and Hoflund [16], Pd supported on MnO x , CeO2, TiO2, CoO x , and Al2O3 have been examined for CO oxidation activity near stoichiometric conditions and it was found that the Pd/CeO2 catalyst possessed the highest reactivity. Concerning the reaction mechanism for CO oxidation over supported catalyst, it is generally believed that the reaction takes place at the metal-support interface [17]. However, the nature of the active sites/phase is still under discussion. For example, for the supported Pd-CeO2 catalysts, Venezia [18] noted that the Pd and PdO species are the active sites for CO oxidation reaction. Kulshreshtha [19] concluded that the formation of non-stoichiometric PdO x has a certain promoting effect. Bera [20] reported that the observed enhanced catalytic activity of Pd/CeO2 could be attributed to the ionic dispersion of Pd on CeO2 leading to a strong metal–ceria interaction in the form of Ce1−x Pd x O2−δ solid solution. In our earlier work on comparing the specific reaction rate of free PdO species on the surface of catalysts and Pd2+ ions in Ce1−x Pd x O2−δ solid solution. It was found that free PdO species had a higher specific reaction rate (969.3μmolCO gPd −1 s−1) than Pd2+ ions in solid solution (13.2μmolCO gPd −1 s−1) [21]. Although the surface PdO species were much more active than the Pd2+ ions in solid solution, activity in terms of turnover frequency (TOF) is more desirable to evaluate the intrinsic activity of the catalyst. Because the activity in terms of specific reaction rate (e.g. μmolCO gPd −1 s−1) neglects the effect of metal dispersion. In a recent review article, turnover frequency (TOF) is used to evaluate the catalytic performance of the Au/TiO2 [22], Au x Pd y /SiO2 [23], and Cu/TiO2 [24] catalysts in CO oxidation or describe the CO2 formation rate (molecule site−1s−1) on the Pd (100), (111) and (110) surfaces with reactants of various O2/CO ratios [25]. Therefore, in the present work, a series of PdO-CeO2/SiO2 catalysts were prepared using impregnation method. The catalysts were calcined at different temperatures and thus PdO species with various particle sizes could be obtained. Moreover, due to the thermal treatment, some Pd2+ ions could penetrate into the CeO2 matrix to form the Ce1−x Pd x O2−δ solid solution. By a nitric acid treatment, free surface PdO species could be removed. Special attention is given to compare the CO oxidation activity of free PdO and Pd2+ ions by calculating the turnover frequencies (TOFs) based on the results of CO chemisorption. It showed that the TOF of the surface PdO species was higher than that of Ce1−x Pd x O2−δ solid solution. This could give some help to the identification of the active sites for CO oxidation over PdO-CeO2 catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation A series of PdO-CeO2/SiO2 catalysts were prepared by conventional impregnation method. A certain quantity of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O(>99.0%) was impregnated onto SiO2 (specific surface area: 41m2 g−1, particle size: 20–40 mesh) with a CeO2 loading of 10wt%. The mixture was dried at 90°C under stirring, and then the solid was dried at 120°C overnight, followed by calcination at 500°C for 4h in air. The catalyst was denoted as CS-5. Supported Pd catalysts were prepared by impregnating the obtained CeO2/SiO2 with an aqueous solution of Pd(NO3)2 for 12h, and the Pd loadings in the catalysts was 1wt%. The suspension was dried at 90°C under stirring, and then the solid was dried at 120°C overnight, followed by the calcination at 400, 500, 600 and 700°C for 4h in air. The catalysts were denoted as PCS-4, PCS-5, PCS-6 and PCS-7, respectively. A reference PdO/SiO2 catalyst was prepared using the same impregnation method as mentioned above, with a Pd loading of 1wt%. The catalyst was denoted as PS-5. The obtained PdO-CeO2/SiO2 catalysts were divided into two groups. One group was reserved, and the other was subjected to nitric acid treatment for comparison. Taking PCS-4 for an example, the catalyst was immersed and stirred in concentrated nitric acid (15.2mol/L, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., China) at 250°C for 1h then filtered. The above process was repeated for three times. Finally, the obtained solid was washed with plenty of deionized water to remove the residual nitric acid and dried at 90°C. The catalyst was denoted as PCS-4H, which means that the catalyst was treated with nitric acid. 2.2 Characterizations X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on a PANalytical X’Pert PRO MPD powder diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ =0.15418nm). The working voltage was 40kV and the working current was 40mA. The patterns were collected in a 2θ range from 10 to 110°. The mean crystallite size was calculated by Scherrer equation: D = Kλ/βcosθ, where D is crystallite size; K is a constant near unity; λ =0.15418nm is the wave length of the X-ray; β is the half peak width of the XRD; θ is the Bragg angle. The lattice parameter was determined by the Rietveld method using JADE 6.5 software. Specific surface areas (SBET) of the catalysts were measured from a multipoint Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) analysis of the nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms at 77K, recorded on a Quantachrome Autosorb-1 apparatus. Before measurement, the sample was dried at 100°C for 4h under vacuum. The amount of CO chemisorption was carried out on a Quan-tachrame CHEMBET-3000 instrument. 200mg of the sample was placed in a quartz U-tube and was reduced in a H2-N2 mixture (5vol% H2, 30mlmin−1) stream at 200°C for 60min, and purged with He for 1h to remove residual H2 and N2, then cooled down to 30°C in a pure He flow (30mlmin−1). Then pulses of CO were fed into the stream of carrier gas with a precision analytical syringe. Assuming that the number of CO molecules adsorbed on the catalyst equals to the number of surface active sites of catalyst. Reducibility of the catalysts was measured by the hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) technique. 50mg of the sample was placed in a quartz reactor connected to a homemade TPR apparatus and the reactor was heated from 40 to 800°C with a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1, in a reducing atmosphere of mixed H2 (5vol.%) and N2 (95vol.%) with a total flow rate of 30mlmin−1. The amount of H2 uptake during the reduction was measured by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD), calibrated by using a known amount of pure CuO powder. The water produced in TPR was trapped on a 5Å molecular sieve. Raman spectra were recorded on a Renishaw RM1000 with a confocal microprobe Raman system using two laser excitation lines of 514 and 325nm 2.3 Catalytic testing CO oxidation was carried out in a quartz tubular (i.d.=6mm) fixed-bed reactor under atmospheric pressure. 200mg of the catalyst was loaded into the reactor and the reaction temperature was monitored by a thermocouple placed in the middle of the catalyst bed. A mixture of 1vol.% CO and 1vol.% O2 balanced with N2 was introduced as the reactants. The total flow rate was 40mlmin−1, corresponding to a space velocity of 12000mlgcat −1 h−1. The catalyst was directly exposed to the reaction without any pretreatment. The CO concentration in the reactor effluent was analyzed using an Agilent 6850 gas chromatograph equipped with a TCD detector and an HP PLOT (30m×0.32mm×12μm) column. The CO conversion of the sample was measured as a function of temperature (light-off curve). Conversion of CO was calculated as follows: (1) CO conversion ( % ) = [ CO ] in vol . % − [ CO ] out vol . % [ CO ] in vol . % × 100 where [CO]in and [CO]out were the CO concentrations in the feed gas (vol.%) and products (vol.%), respectively. The calculation of turnover frequencies (TOFs) based on the conversion of CO and the amount of active sites measured by CO chemisorption. Assuming that the number of CO molecules adsorbed on the PCS and PCS-H catalysts equals to the number of surface active sites. Noting that PCS catalysts contain free PdO species and Pd2+ ions and thus the CO conversion over the PCS catalysts contains the contributions of these two species. Consequently, the TOFs of PCS and PCS-H catalysts were calculated as follows: (2) TOF PdO = ( Conv a − Conv b ) × F CO S a − S b TOF Pd 2 + = Conv b × F CO S b where FCO is the flow rate of CO. TOFPdO and TOFPd 2+ are the TOFs of free PdO and Pd2+ ions, respectively. Conva and Sa refer to the conversion of CO and the amount of the active sites for PCS catalysts. Convb and Sb refer to the conversion of CO and the amount of the active sites for PCS-H catalysts. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characterization Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the catalysts. It is found that the peak characteristic of amorphous phase SiO2 at 21.8° is observed in all the catalysts. In addition, two strong peaks characteristic of CeO2 at 28.5° and 47.5° are also detected in CS-5, PCS-4, PCS-5, PCS-6 and PCS-7 catalysts. With increasing calcination temperature, the intensities of CeO2 peaks hardly increase, implying that the growth of bulk CeO2 crystallite is not obvious. Diffraction peaks due to PdO species at 33.8° is observed in PS-5 catalyst. However, this diffraction peak is not detected in PCS-4, PCS-5, PCS-6 and PCS-7 catalysts, owning to the fact that follows: (a) the lower Pd contents (1wt%) in the catalysts; (b) Pd species may be highly dispersed on the surface of catalysts; (c) the overlapping diffraction peaks of PdO and CeO2 species. The results for the lattice parameters of PCS and CS-5 catalysts are summarized in Table 1 . It can be seen that the lattice parameters of PCS catalysts decrease slightly compared to that of CS-5 catalyst. This suggests that some Pd2+ ions incorporate into the ceria lattice to form a Ce1−x Pd x O2−δ solid solution: the radius of Pd2+ ion (0.84Å) is smaller than that of Ce4+ (0.99Å). The catalysts are also characterized by Raman spectroscopy in order to obtain surface information. Fig. 2 a shows the Raman spectra of the PS-5, CS-5 and PCS catalysts. The band at 460cm−1 is ascribed to the F2g vibration mode of the fluorite structure of CeO2 [26]. The band at 645cm−1 is attributed to the PdO species [27,28], which means that the PdO species exists on the surface of PCS and PS catalysts. In contrast to PCS-4 catalyst, the band intensity of PCS-5, PCS-6 and PCS-7 catalysts at 645cm−1 increases slightly. Fig. 2b shows the Raman spectra of the PCS-H catalysts. Compared to the PCS catalysts, the bands at 645cm−1 of PCS-H catalysts disappeared, indicating that the PdO species had been removed by the nitric acid treatment. Fig. 3 shows the Raman spectra of the catalysts with 325nm laser excitation line. UV-Raman spectroscopy reflects the outer surface information of the catalyst [29], which is due to the strong absorption properties of the catalyst in the UV region. The bands at 465cm−1 are ascribed to the F2g vibration mode of the fluorite structure of CeO2 [xxvi]. The bands at 592cm−1 are ascribed to oxygen vacancies [30]. Clearly, the intensity of the bands at 592cm−1 for the PCS-H catalysts is considerably stronger than the CS catalyst. The peak areas of the bands at 465, 592cm−1 are calculated based on the results shown in Fig. 3, which are denoted as A465 and A592, respectively. The ratio A592/A465 reflects the concentration of oxygen vacancies in the catalysts [31]. It is found that the values of PCS-H catalysts (1.21 (PCS-4H), 1.19 (PCS-5H) 1.18 PCS-6H 1.22 PCS-7H)) are higher than that of CS-5 catalyst (0.96). This suggests that oxygen vacancies created in PCS-H catalysts, which due to the Pd2+cations penetrated into the ceria lattice to form the Ce1−x Pd x O2−δ solid solution. The Raman spectroscopy experiments give a further information is that the PCS catalysts contain free PdO species and Pd2+ ions, and the free PdO species on the surface of catalysts could be removed by nitric acid treatment. The specific surface area and CeO2 crystallite size of catalysts are listed in Table 1. It can be seen that the specific surface area of PCS catalysts decreases from 103 to 90 m2 g−1 with increasing calcination temperature. However, the CeO2 crystallite sizes of catalysts remain around 13.5nm 3.2 Reduction properties of the catalysts The reduction properties of the PCS, PS-5, CS-5 and PCS-H catalysts are analyzed by H2-TPR, as shown in Fig. 4 . It can be seen that there are two reduction peaks (α and β), except for the PS-5 and CS-5 catalysts in Fig. 4a. The former peak (peak α) could be assigned to the reduction of free surface PdO species [32], and the latter (peak β) could be assigned to the reduction of surface Ce4+ [33]. Comparing the reduction peak areas of PCS-5 and PS-5 catalysts (Table 2 ), it is found that the former has a larger peak area than the latter, implying that the formation of Ce1−x Pd x O2−δ solid solution promotes the reduction properties of the catalysts. This could be interpreted as that surface free PdO species is easily reduced to metallic Pd0 species, which could activate hydrogen and consequently reduce the adjacent Ce4+ due to the spillover effect [34]. Fig. 4b shows the H2-TPR profiles of PCS-H catalysts. For the nitric acid-treated catalysts, two reduction peaks (α and β) are detected. The peaks α and β could be assigned to the reduction of Pd2+ ions in the Ce1−x Pd x O2−δ solid solution and the reduction of Ce4+ on the surface of catalysts, respectively [35]. Compared to the PCS catalysts, the reduction peak area decreased obviously, implying that the decrease of the oxidative species in the catalysts after the nitric acid treatment. With increasing calcination temperature, the area of peak α in PCS-H catalysts increases due to more Pd2+ ions are incorporated into the CeO2 lattice to form the Ce1−x Pd x O2−δ solid solution, upon calcination temperature. In contrast to Fig. 4a, Fig. 4b shows that the reduction temperature of PCS-H catalysts is higher than that of PCS catalysts. This is because the free surface PdO is easier to be reduced to metallic Pd0 compared to the Pd2+ ions in the Ce1−x Pd x O2−δ solid solution. Meanwhile, with increasing calcination temperature, the reduction temperature of the PCS-H catalysts shifts to lower temperature gradually. This could be correlated with that more Pd2+ ions are incorporated into the CeO2 lattice, which promotes the reduction of Ce1−x Pd x O2−δ solid solution. However, the decreasing of the peak area of PCS-H catalysts (Fig. 4b) due to the different crystallinity of CeO2 could not be excluded and needs a further investigation. 3.3 Catalytic activity Fig. 5 shows the catalytic activities of the catalysts. It can be seen that PCS catalysts are more active than the PS-5 and CS-5 catalyst (Fig. 5a). However, the reactivity of PCS catalysts (maximal value of TOF (PCS-6) is 0.015s−1) is lower than that of PdO/Ce1−x Pd x O2−δ catalyst (TOF=0.12s−1) prepared by solution-combustion method reported in the previous papers [xxi] [xxxiii]. This may be due to the fact that the inactive SiO2 was adopted as supporter and the lower Pd contents (1wt%) in the catalysts. In addition, the particle size of PdO (1.4nm) on the PdO/Ce1−x Pd x O2−δ catalyst determined by CO chemisorption was smaller than that in this work (about 3.0nm). The PCS-6 catalyst has the highest activity among all the catalysts. However, the activity of the PCS-7 catalyst decreased. This may be due to the fact that more Pd2+ ions are incorporated into the CeO2 lattice to form the Ce1−x Pd x O2−δ solid solution, which leads to the decreasing of PdO species on the surface of catalysts. Compared to the PCS catalysts, the activity of PCS-H catalysts (Fig. 5b) decreased sharply and even has a lower activity than PS-5 catalyst, indicating that the free PdO has a key role for the CO oxidation. Furthermore, the PCS-7H catalyst has the highest activity among the PCS-H catalysts, owning to the fact that more Ce1−x Pd x O2−δ solid solution formed on the PCS-7H catalyst. This means that the formation of Ce1−x Pd x O2−δ solid solution promotes the CO oxidation activity of the PCS-H catalysts. Turnover frequencies (TOFs) based on the amount of CO adsorption of free PdO species on the surface of catalysts and Pd2+ ions in Ce1−x Pd x O2−δ solid solution are calculated and listed in Table 3 . With increasing calcination temperature, the TOFs of free PdO species increased from 0.0214 to 0.038s−1 and the TOFs of Pd2+ ions increases from 0.0012 to 0.0056s−1. This means that higher calcination temperature is beneficial to improving the CO oxidation reactivity of these catalysts. However, the TOF of free PdO species on the surface of PS-5 catalyst is much lower than that on the surface of PCS-5 catalyst. This may be due to the fact that the existence of Ce1−x Pd x O2−δ solid solution around the PdO species on the PCS catalysts. The PdO species supplies the active sites for CO chemisorption and the Ce1−x Pd x O2−δ solid solution supplies the active sites for oxygen activation (oxygen vacancies) [36], and this synergetic effect could improve the CO catalytic activity of catalysts. In addition, the TOF of free PdO on the surface of PS-5 catalyst is higher than that of Pd2+ ions in the Ce1−x Pd x O2−δ solid solution of the PCS-5H catalyst. This further indicates that the activity of free PdO is higher than the Pd2+ ions. Scheme 1 is the CO reaction model of catalysts. The PCS catalysts both have sites for CO adsorption (free surface PdO species) and oxygen activation (oxygen vacancies), while the PS-5 catalyst contains only free surface PdO species and the PCS-5H catalyst contains only oxygen vacancies. Priolkar et al. [37] reported that the Pd2+ ions was stabilized in the Ce4+ site leading to a strong Pd-CeO2 interaction in the form of Ce1−x Pd x O2−δ solid solution with -Pd2+-O2−-Ce4+- linkages. For PCS-5H catalyst, the CO molecules, adsorbed by Pd2+ ions in Ce1−x Pd x O2−δ solid solution, reacts with adsorbed oxygen species to produce CO2. The turnover frequency follows the order of TOFPdO >TOFPd 2+, implying that the reactivity of PdO is higher than the Pd2+ ions. Moreover, the PCS catalysts have the highest activity, owning to the fact that the synergetic effects of free surface PdO and Ce1−x Pd x O2−δ solid solution. 4 Conclusions In this work, a series of PdO-CeO2/SiO2 catalysts were prepared by an impregnation method and the CO oxidation activities for free surface PdO species and Pd2+ ions over PdO-CeO2/SiO2 catalysts were studied in detail. The results showed that free PdO species and Pd2+ ions were segregated efficiently by nitric acid treatment and the higher calcination temperature promoted the formation of Ce1−x Pd x O2−δ solid solution. PdO-CeO2/SiO2 catalyst calcined at 600°C had the highest CO oxidation performance and the TOF of free PdO (3.27×10−2 s−1) was higher than that of the Pd2+ ions in the Ce1−x Pd x O2−δ solid solution (0.49×10−2 s−1). The CO catalytic activities of PdO-CeO2/SiO2 catalysts were higher than that of PdO/SiO2 catalyst and PdO-CeO2/SiO2 catalysts after nitric acid treatment. Moreover, the CO catalytic activity of PdO-CeO2/SiO2 could be assigned to the synergetic effects of free surface PdO species and Ce1−x Pd x O2−δ solid solution, and this effect improved the CO catalytic activity of catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Aiming at comparing the CO oxidation activity of free PdO and Pd2+ ions, a series of PdO-CeO2/SiO2 catalysts were prepared via an impregnation method and the turnover frequencies of them were quantitatively evaluated. The catalysts were further characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET), temperature-programmed reduction (TPR), Raman technique and CO chemisorption. It was found that free PdO species and Pd2+ ions could be segregated efficiently by nitric acid treatment. The PdO-CeO2/SiO2 catalyst calcined at 600°C showed the highest activity. The results of CO chemisorption suggested that free PdO species had a higher activity than Pd2+ ions, and the turnover frequencies of them were 3.27×10−2 s−1 and 0.49×10−2 s−1, respectively. The activity of PdO-CeO2/SiO2 catalyst was higher than that of PdO/SiO2 catalyst. Moreover, the CO catalytic activity of PdO-CeO2/SiO2 catalyst could be assigned to the synergetic effect of free PdO and Pd2+ ions, and this effect could improve the CO catalytic activity of catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Comparing the CO oxidation activity of free PdO and Pd2+ ions over PdO-CeO2/SiO2 catalysts
